newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-CONTROVERSIAL PENALTY TAKES CHELSEA THROUGH.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-CONTROVERSIAL PENALTY TAKES CHELSEA THROUGH.

text.p: A bitterly disputed penalty in the 117th minute gave Chelsea a 1-0 victory over Leicester in a compelling English F.A. Cup fifth round replay on Wednesday.

Referee Mike Reed adjudged Leicester's Matt Elliott had barged Chelsea's Norwegian Erland Johnsen as he closed in on goal in the dying minutes of extra-time after the initial 90 minutes ended goalless.
The decision appeared harsh and the Leicester players swarmed around Reed in protest.

When the pushing and shoving had ended French fullback Franck Leboeuf converted the spot kick and three minutes later Chelsea were through to the quarter-finals where they will meet first division Portsmouth.
The decision and the final result were all the more cruel for Leicester as they had held their own against Ruud Gullit's talented Chelsea side throughout the evening.
Leicester manager Martin O'Neill, whose side had hauled themselves back into the original tie to draw 2-2 after being 2-0 down, appeared shell-shocked after the match.
"It's unbelievable, absolutely unbelievable," he said. The referee was five yards (metres) away when he gave the penalty. That is shocking. It's a disgrace.
"The players have been heroic and to go out like that is heart-breaking.
"I felt I had all the players behind me. I was sure I would score," he said.
In the night's other fifth round tie, Derby fought back from 2-0 down to win 3-2 courtesy of an 88th minute winner from Dean Sturridge.
Coventry, suprise F.A. Cup winners in 1987, surged ahead in the first 13 minutes thanks to goals from in-form Darren Huckerby and Noel Whelan.
But Derby were level by the interval and clawed their way into the last eight thanks to Sturridge's dramatic late strike, his 10th goal of the season.

Derby's quarter-final opponents Middlesbrough took a big step towards their first major final when they won 2-0 at second division Stockport in a semifinal first leg tie in England's other cup competition, the League Cup.
Danish striker Mikkel Beck scored Middlesbrough's first, beating the Stockport offside trap after 73 minutes and sliding a shot through the goalkeeper's legs.
Italy's Fabrizio Ravanelli added a second on a rain-soaked pitch at Stockport's tiny Edgeley Park ground, packed with a capacity 12,000 fans.
Stockport, conquerers of premier league Blackburn, West Ham and Southampton in previous rounds, now have a mountain to climb in the second leg at the Riverside stadium.
In the night's only premier league match Wimbledon drew 0-0 at Southampton to go fifth in the table, 11 points behind leaders Manchester United with two games in hand.
